The Act titled "Designer Anabolic Steroid Control Act of 2014" makes amendments to the Controlled Substances Act by adding new substances to the list of controlled substances. The Act "Designer Anabolic Steroid Control Act of 2014" adds new substances to the list of controlled substances, including various synthetic steroids like 4-chloro-17a-methyl-androsta-1,4-diene-3,17b-diol and 2a,17a-dimethyl-17b-hydroxy-5a-androstan-3-one. The Act "Designer Anabolic Steroid Control Act of 2014" includes new substances like 4-Hydroxy-androst-4-ene-3,17-dione[3,2-c]pyrazole-5a-androstan-17b-ol, [3,2-c]pyrazole-androst-4-en-17b-ol, and [3,2-c]pyrazole-5a-androstan-17b-ol. It also defines criteria for substances to be considered anabolic steroids based on their intended effects on muscle growth or testosterone-like pharmacological effects. The Act "Designer Anabolic Steroid Control Act of 2014" defines criteria for substances to be considered anabolic steroids based on their intended effects on muscle growth or testosterone-like pharmacological effects. A substance is not considered a drug or hormonal substance if it is an herb, botanical, dietary ingredient, and not anabolic or androgenic. The Act "Designer Anabolic Steroid Control Act of 2014" defines criteria for substances to be considered anabolic steroids based on their intended effects on muscle growth or testosterone-like pharmacological effects. Any person claiming an exemption under clause (ii) must provide evidence. The Attorney General can temporarily add substances to the definition of anabolic steroids if they meet certain criteria. The Attorney General can temporarily add drugs to the definition of anabolic steroids to prevent abuse. An order issued must be published in the Federal Register and expires within 24 months, with a possible 6-month extension. The Attorney General must notify the Secretary of Health and Human Services before issuing such an order. The Attorney General can issue temporary scheduling orders for drugs considered anabolic steroids, which expire upon the issuance of a permanent scheduling order. Such orders are not subject to judicial review. The Attorney General may also issue a permanent order adding a substance to the definition of anabolic steroids if it meets the criteria. SEC. 3. LABELING REQUIREMENTS.
    Amends Section 305 of the Controlled Substances Act to make it unlawful to import, export, manufacture, distribute, dispense, or possess anabolic steroids without proper labeling as per IUPAC nomenclature. Certain products are exempt from this requirement if labeled accordingly. The subsection clarifies that certain products are exempt from labeling requirements if they meet specific criteria under the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act. Additionally, a clarification is made to the Import and Export Statute under the Controlled Substances Act. The Controlled Substances Import and Export Act (21 U.S.C. 960) is amended to include penalties for violating subsection (e) of section 825. Amendments are also made to Section 402 of the Controlled Substances Act (21 U.S.C. 842) regarding civil penalties for violations. Penalties for violating subsection (e) of section 825 of the Controlled Substances Import and Export Act include fines of up to $500,000 per violation for importers, exporters, manufacturers, or distributors. For distribution, dispensing, or possession with intent to distribute at the retail level, fines can be up to $1000 per violation. Retail level refers to products sold directly to consumers for personal use. SEC. 4. IDENTIFICATION AND PUBLICATION OF LIST OF PRODUCTS CONTAINING ANABOLIC STEROIDS. The Attorney General may collect data to determine products containing anabolic steroids and publish a list of non-compliant products. The absence of a product from the list does not indicate compliance. The absence of a product from the list does not indicate compliance with the identification and publication of products containing anabolic steroids.
